The  Project  will  raise  the  quality  of  secondary  education,  make
schooling  more  attractive  for  grades  10-13  students,  and  encourage
especially  rural  and  disadvantaged  students  to  continue  studies.
Especially  important  will  be  quality  improvements  to  language

students  attending  grades  10-13  each  year  will  benefit  from  the
program  over  the  five-year  project  period  and  the  subsequent  five-
year period after project completion. The Project will increase access
to  100  upgraded  full-curriculum  schools  for  about  5,000  additional
disadvantaged  students  annually  over  10  years;  provide  stipends  to
30,000  disadvantaged  students  to  attend  existing  full-curriculum
schools  over  five  years;  and  provide  all  students  with  information
about education, training, and jobs. The Project will also improve the
delivery  of  secondary  education  by  strengthening  the  capacity  of
MEHE  to  plan  and  coordinate  monitoring  and  supervision  of  quality
improvements  at  the  central  and  local  level  for  up  to  6,000
administrators.

The Project will assist NETS to improve the examination system. The
change is expected to increase the pass rates at 0 level enabling an
average  additional  50,000  students  (age  16)  per  year  over  12  years
to quality for entry into grade 12, many of whom would otherwise fail
to quality. About 32 NETS staff will be trained and given fellowships.

INTRODUCTION

2.
Following  the  release  of  the  Presidential  Task  Force  Report  on  General  Education  in
1998, the Government of Sri Lanka took steps to modernize the secondary education system.
Modernizing secondary schools will help to increase access to quality education and make the
country  more  competitive.  In  April  1999,  the  Government  requested  the  Asian  Development
Bank  (ADB)  to  support  secondary  education  modernization.  In  response  to  this  request,  ADB
assisted the Government to undertake a feasibility study1 from October 1998 to January 1999,
employing  a  participatory  approach  with  central,  provincial,  district,  zonal,  and  divisional
education  officials,  principals,  teachers,  parents,  students,  and  nongovernment  organizations
(NGOs).  The  consultative  process  involved  workshops  and  school  meetings  to  confirm  the
demand  for  computer  learning,  and  local  involvement  in  monitoring  and  supporting  the  use  of
computer  learning  centers  (CLCs).  Meetings  were  held  among  ADB,  Japan  International
Cooperation  Agency  (JICA),  Japan  Bank  for  International  Cooperation  (JBIC),  and  the
Government  to  plan  strategies  for  future  widespread  use  of  school  computers.  A  Loan  Fact-
Finding  Mission  was  conducted  in  April  2000  and  appraisal  in  June  2000.2  This  proposal  is
based  on  the  findings  of  the  feasibility  report,  ADB  Missions  and  subsequent  staff  work.
Appendix 1 presents the project framework.

BACKGROUND

A.

Sector Description

1.

Socioeconomic Context

3.
Sri  Lanka’s  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  grew  5.2  percent  per  annum  during  the
1990s. In 1998, the per capita GDP averaged $823. Although the GDP growth rate has slowed
in recent years, the Government has achieved macroeconomic stability with single-digit inflation
and a fiscal deficit lower than that in the mid-1990s, despite the economic and political instability
in the region. The Government achieved considerable progress in the structural reform agenda
that includes tax reform and the reduction of public sector dominance through increased public-
private sector participation. Curtailing public sector employment already has contributed toward
private sector growth and the reduction of educated unemployment from 29 percent in 1990 to
19 percent in 1998. The continued emphasis on human resources is needed to prepare a skilled
labor force capable of taking advantage of new global trends in technology-based, value-added
jobs,  and  to  promote  labor-intensive  products  in  agriculture,  tourism,  and  manufacturing.
Without a strong skill and knowledge base, the Government believes it is unlikely that Sri Lanka
can compete in the regional and global economy.

2.

The Secondary Education System

The  education  system  in  Sri  Lanka  comprises  nine  years  of  basic  education  and  four
5.
years of secondary education comprising two years of ordinary (O level) study (grades 10-11)
and two years of advanced (A level) study (grades 12-13). Out of about 4 million students in the
school  system  of  10,000  schools,  about  one  million  students  are  in  the  secondary  grades  in
about 2,300 schools. About 40,000 of the 180,000 teachers in the system teach in these upper
grades.4 Education is compulsory through age 14 to enforce universal basic education and the
Government aims to extend compulsory education to age 16 (grade 11), but at present although
about 90 percent of students complete grade 11, only one third continue to grade 12 as most of
them  are  unable  to  pass  the  O  level  examination  taken  after  grade  11.  In  fact,  15  percent  of
grade  11  students  fail  all  subjects  on  the  O  level  examination.  This  unsatisfactory  academic
performance is a key indicator of the poor quality of teaching and learning in secondary schools.
The  failure  of  these  students  to  attain  minimum  achievement  levels  results  in  significant
wastage  of  financial  resources.  Lack  of  educational  facilities,  teaching  materials,  and  learning
resources  is  the  root  cause  of  the  low  quality  of  teaching  and  limited  coverage  of  secondary
education.

Currently, there are two types of secondary schools: the first consists of about 600 full-

rural communities and lack science teachers and facilities for teaching science. Students in the

3.

School Access and the Poor

7.
About one million students attend secondary school: 350,000 each in grades 10 and 11,
and  about  150,000  each  in  grades  12  and  13.    Enrollments  are  now  declining  by  about  1
percent  per  annum  in  the  primary  grades  and  this  will  eventually  lead  to  decline  in  secondary
school  enrollments  thereby  removing  budgetary  pressure  to  expand  education  resources.
Currently, dropping out occurs only between grades 11 and 12 as students fail the examination
in great numbers, however, they can repeat grade 11 and sit for the examination a second time.
The  same  also  holds  for  the  national  examination  taken  after  grade  13.  Because  over  90
percent of students aged 15 and 16 attend grades 10 and 11, most students from poor families
are in school until they drop out after grade 11 when they fail the grade 11 national examination.

8.
Of  the  2,300  secondary  schools,  about  10  percent  are  large  schools  with  more  than
1,000  students.  These  schools  are  in  large  cities  and  provincial  capitals.  Another  50  percent
have  enrollments  of  about  500.  The  remaining  40  percent  have  small  enrollments,  often  lack
electricity  and  teachers,  and  taken  together  do  not  enroll  more  than  20  percent  of  secondary
school  students.  For  this  reason,  focusing  on  about  35  percent  of  all  secondary  schools  can
cover  almost  all  grades  12-13  students  and  up  to  one  third  of  grades  10-11  students.  These
schools  comprise  both  good  and  bad  performing  schools  and  so  a  careful  rationalization  of
school juxtaposition is required to ensure that each community has access to a high-performing
school. The well-performing schools generally exclude economically poor students who perform
poorly on academic tests due to a lack of resources at home. At least half of students in poor
performing  schools  are  economically  disadvantaged,  while  about  30  percent  of  students
attending high-quality schools are economically poor.

9.
The problem of access to quality schooling is complicated because students sometimes
will not attend schools dominated by those of another cultural background. Also, some schools
do  not  offer  a  full  set  of  academic  choices  especially  in  grades  12-13,  so  students  wishing  to
study science, for example, often transfer to another school to study science or else switch to
arts  or  commerce  in  their  own  school.  The  Government  provides  a  stipend  program  for  bright
students in grades 6 through 11, and the President’s office recently initiated a pilot program to
provide stipends for students in secondary school who do well on their grade 9 examinations.
What is further needed are stipends targeted to poor but promising students in grades 10 and
11 to help them to attend better schools and to provide them with remedial assistance so they
can  pass  the  O  level  examination.  Other  stipends  can  be  targeted  to  successful  O  level
candidates,  who  would  otherwise  drop  out,  to  enable  them  to  attend  grades  12-13.  School
development societies (SDSs) provide assistance to needy students in cooperation with school
principals.  The  national  safety  net  Samurdhi  program  also  provides  direct  income  support  to
nearly  50  percent  of  all  families.  Together  these  programs  help  to  meet  the  needs  of
disadvantaged students in schools but despite them, only about half of the students can afford
the  voluntary  fees  requested  by  SDS.  The  situation  indicates  the  extent  of  student  poverty  in
schools.

4. 

The Secondary School Curriculum and Learning

10.
Secondary  schools  follow  a  standard  curriculum  and  syllabus  in  each  grade.  However,
some  schools  offer  only  the  arts  or  commerce  syllabus,  or  both,  while  others  offer  in  addition
science  courses  in  grades  12-13.  The  schools  that  offer  science  require  science  laboratories
and  must  be  staffed  with  qualified  science  teachers  in  physics,  mathematics,  biology,  and
chemistry. Typically, students attend classes where the traditional chalk-and-talk method is the
rule and have access to a school library. To alter classroom teaching and textbook learning, the
Government,  under  the  new  education  reforms,  has  introduced  project  work  and  field  studies
requiring  students  to  access  greater  amounts  of  knowledge  and  information  outside  the
classroom.  For  example,  in  grades  12-13,  textbooks  are  not  provided  and  teachers  often  lack
specific  training.  The  Ministry  of  Education  and  Higher  Education  (MEHE)  plans  to  provide
multiple textbooks to be placed in school libraries for reference and include multimedia rooms
with  television,  video  cassette  recorder  (VCR)  and  audio  cassettes  to  provide  students  with
learning materials separate from the traditional textbook and lecture format. Language cassettes
to improve pronunciation are another example of the multimedia approach to classroom learning
in  Sri  Lanka.  The  National  Institute  of  Education  (NIE)  was  established  under  the  National
Education  Act  (No.  28  of  1985).  NIE,  which  is  responsible  for  curriculum  development  and  in-
service curriculum training, is introducing innovative programs to introduce applied science and
technology  in  grades  12-13  that  allow  students  to  apply  physics  and  biology  in  everyday
problem solving.

11.
NIE  has  produced  a  syllabus  for  computer  literacy  that  emphasizes  both  information
technology  (IT)  and  interactive  learning.  The  Government  would  like  to  include  a  computer
laboratory in every school, but at the moment will require the subject to be mandatory only for
grades  12-13.  Computer  laboratories  are  expected  to  increase  access  to  electronic  reference
materials, and software materials to supplement science, mathematics, English, and commerce
lessons, but eventually will allow access to the Internet, tutorials, and other interactive computer
learning  activities  that  are  expected  to  change  the  way  students  learn  lessons.  NIE  is
developing a system to download free academic software off the Internet and provide compact
disk-read only memory (CD-ROM) via private service providers to school computer laboratories.
In summary, the use of new educational technologies in grades 10-13 is becoming a reality. The
Government  does  not  want  its  schools  left  behind  those  of  other  countries  and  it  regards  the
benefits  of  those  technologies  as  important  because  they  can  supplement  the  information,
knowledge,  and  pedagogical  style  of  classroom  teachers  to  help  improve  student  learning.
These  new  technologies  also  offer  additional  avenues  for  study  so  that  teachers  can  easily
assess individual and group progress.

5.

The Examination System

12.
Secondary education follows the traditional British system of two years (grades 10-11) of
schooling  followed  by  the  O  level  national  examination.  Successful  completion  of  this  national
examination allows the student to attend two additional years of secondary school (grades 12-
13)  followed  by  the  A  level  national  examination.  Currently,  about  35  percent  of  students
successfully pass the O level examination (up from 24 percent in 1990) and about 45 percent
pass  the  A  level  examination  (this  rate  has  remained  steady  over  the  past  10  years  as  the
examination  serves  mainly  as  a  determinant  of  university  entrance  rather  than  a  test  of
secondary school completion).

 5

Each  of  these  one-shot  examinations  evaluates  two  years  of  education  assessed  in
13.
several  hours  of  testing.  While  the  examination  system  remains  honest  and  highly  respected,
many view it as an anachronism that disallows continuous assessment throughout the year for
assignments,  projects,  and  coursework  graded  by  the  teacher.  Furthermore,  parents  pay  for
private tutoring after school to give an advantage to their children. Only about 50 percent of the
students  can  afford  the  tutorial  costs  and  the  system  detracts  from  ensuring  that  in-school
teaching  is  maximized.  In  the  past,  the  national  examination  was  thought  to  be  a  meritocratic
way  to  select  students  for  public  sector  employment.  Today,  public  sector  employment  is
minimal and those continuing on to the university represent only about 10 percent of successful
A  level  candidates.  Consequently,  an  examination  system  that  counts  secondary  school
coursework,  especially  science  laboratory  work,  student  projects  in  English,  mathematics,
commerce, and computer work that can be used by employers to judge student qualifications for
work  and  on-job-training  is  preferable  to  the  existing  examination  system  that  labels  students
either as winners or losers. The Government has mandated school-based assessment (SBA) in
grades  6-9  to  allow  teachers  to  evaluate  students  on  both  academic  and  attitudinal  attributes.
Starting  in  2001,  the  system  will  be  introduced  in  grades  10-13  and  linked  to  the  national
examination system. While government officials and academicians view the current system as
antiquated, the public continues to see the national examination as a highly important measure
of  student  success.  For  this  reason,  the  public  is  reluctant  to  change  the  examination  system
that is seen by many as the only way to be judged competent.

14.
The examination system is run by the Department of Examinations (DOE) that recently
moved  its  operations  from  18th  century  slave  quarters.  The  unit  responsible  for  national
examinations  is  the  National  Evaluation  and  Testing  Service  (NETS),  which  is  presently
established within MEHE. NETS is responsible for conducting the O and A level examinations
each  year.  The  O  level  examination  is  carried  out  in  December,  results  are  released  in  April,
and the student resumes schooling in August (a nine-month interruption of studies). Grade 13
candidates  take  their  examinations  in  August,  learn  results  in  December,  and  resume  studies
the following December (a 15-month interruption in study). NETS staff view the carrying out of
the  examinations  as  their  most  important  function.  While  NETS  has  new  equipment  to  secure
test printing and distribution, and computers for consolidating scores by test readers, the system
lacks funding, staffing, and management. Little research is conducted and no one is looking at
ways to improve efficiency in test administration.

6.

Secondary School Management and Supervision

MEHE is responsible for managing the education system, especially for setting policies
15.
and  standards.  MEHE  was  recently  reorganized  to  strengthen  its  planning,  policy,  and
monitoring  capacity  because  routine  tasks  including  personnel,  budgeting,  etc.  have  been
delegated  to  the  local  administration.  Consequently,  the  reorganization  has  stressed  quality
assurance.  Further,  MEHE  has  increased  its  control  over  teacher  education  institutes  and
exercises  closer  control  over  curriculum  development  (NIE)  and  school-based  assessment
(SBA, NETS). Both NETS and NIE are now more closely coordinated and supervised by MEHE,
with MEHE taking responsibility for curriculum and examination policies.

16.
The  Government  recently  took  steps  to  restructure  MEHE  to  include  a  deputy  director
general  of  school  management  quality  assurance  responsible  for  line  supervision  and  for
ensuring  that  academic  standards  are  maintained.    The  supervision  component  was
strengthened  to  provide  a  greater  line  of  control  from  national,  provincial,  district,  zonal,  and
divisional  offices  to  schools.  Under  the  reorganization,  a  deputy  director  general  for  quality
assurance was designated to oversee quality assurance, and this has taken the form of school-

 6

based  management  (SBM)  with  the  principal,  SDS  leader,  and  zonal  officer  pivotal  in  making
the system effective. Strong MEHE links with provincial and local schools are needed to ensure
good supervision and quality control. Zonal offices are staffed with education officers, but they
require  training.  At  present,  the  top-down  management  structure  allows  for  little  more  than
passing  down  orders  and  does  not  provide  for  two-way  communication.  The  World  Bank  is
providing equipment and training to provincial and zonal offices to improve management for all
10,000 schools so that school principals and SDS leaders will develop new management styles.

7.

Secondary School Finance

17.
The Ministry of Finance and Planning (MOFP) provides funding to the education sector
through  block  grants  directly  to  the  provinces  and  to  the  schools.  In  1998,  approximately  10
percent of the national budget was allocated for education. Of that amount, less than half went
to secondary education. Presently, free education from grade 1 through university is available,
but  this  will  become  untenable  as  more  students  successfully  complete  the  grade  11
examination  and  opt  for  more  education.  The  Government  provides  free  tuition,  textbooks,
uniforms,  and  subsidized  transport.5  Because  the  poor  within  each  ethnic  and  linguistic  group
tend  to  live  in  relatively  homogeneous  communities  isolated  from  one  another,  free  education
can  make  an  important  contribution  to  promoting  social  cohesion  through  a  commonly  shared
schooling  experience.  This  is  a  major  reason  given  for  the  continued  strong  Government
support  for  free  education  throughout  the  country  and  for  the  sensitivity  of  communities  to
changes in the financing of education.

18.
In  1998,  the  Government  spent  2.6  percent  of  GDP  on  education,  which  is  well  below
the  3.5  percent  average  for  Asia.  Educational  expenditures  are  also  relatively  low  as  a
proportion  of  the  overall  government  budget  —  10  percent  in  1998  compared  with  the  14
percent average for Asia. The trend has been gradually declining over the past 10 years. The
ongoing civil conflict is partly to blame for the low expenditures. External sources finance most
capital  investments  while  the  Government  provides  recurrent  costs.    Population  growth  has
stabilized and so have enrollments. About 55 percent of the education budget covers grades 1-9
and  45  percent  is  for  grades  10-13.  With  no  growth  in  enrollments  in  grades  1-9,  these
percentages are likely to remain constant. The education budget has grown at about 10 percent
per  annum  over  the  past  10  years  but,  after  accounting  for  inflation,  the  increase  is  minimal.
With limited funds, it is unlikely that education budgets will increase over the near term. For this
reason, educators will have to do more with less — this will pose problems for improving quality
in the future if funds become scarce.

19.
Because  education  is  free,  students  do  not  pay  for  books,  uniforms,  or  subsidized
transport.  School  fees  account  for  5  percent  of  school  costs  and  families  often  pay  up  to  20
percent of discretionary income on education for children because students require more than
the  one  uniform  provided  and  because  books  are  only  provided  through  grade  11  and  not
always  provided  on  time,  etc.  Parents  also  pay  for  after-school  tutoring  and  facility  fees  in
secondary schools, often as a requirement for acceptance into quality schools. Despite the free
education  policy,  poor  families'  access  to  quality  education  is  constrained  by  their  inability  to
meet the extra costs for books, uniforms, after-school tutoring, and facility fees.

20. When  the  Government  nationalized  schools  in  1968,  it  did  so  to  abolish  the  wide
disparities  in  quality  and  attainment.  Over  the  past  40  years,  the  public  system  has  kept

B.

Government Policies and Plans

21.
The National Education Commission released the report Reforms in General Education
in  1998.  The  report,  based  on  recommendations  from  the  Presidential  Task  Force,  focused
mostly on improving quality through improved curriculum relevance, teaching, and educational
management.  It  also  stressed  extending  educational  opportunities  to  reduce  inequalities
between  students  attending  full-curriculum  and  limited-curriculum  schools.  To  improve  quality
education,  the  Government,  with  World  Bank  assistance,  is  rationalizing  teacher  deployment
and training, privatizing textbook printing and distribution, and consolidating grades 1-9 schools.
In planning the Project, ADB has discussed ways to consolidate grades 10-13 into a four-year
secondary school cycle instead of the present grades 10-11 and grades 12-13 associated with
O and A level examinations. There is a policy to introduce SBA to allow teachers to participate
directly  in  evaluating  and  providing  feedback  to  students  on  academic  and  career  matters,
rather than relying solely on the outcome of national tests.  SBA has already been introduced
successfully in grades 6-9. Other policies are designed to broaden the range of academic skills,
including  improving  English  language  and  computer  literacy.  Policies  being  considered  to
improve educational opportunities include raising compulsory education from grade 9 to grade
11, consolidating grades 10-13, upgrading a number of limited — to full-curriculum schools, and
reforming the O level examination to reduce the failure rate. Other policy considerations include
introducing  career  guidance  and  counseling  for  students  and  parents  to  share  information,
promoting  public-private  partnership  in  education,  and  extending  primary  grades  academic
stipends  to  upper  grade  late  bloomers.  The  World  Bank  and  ADB  strongly  support  these
government policies.

E.

ADB’s Sector Strategy

31.
ADB’s  current  country  operational  strategy  (COS)  was  approved  in  1999.  The  strategy
aims to assist Sri Lanka to reduce poverty and achieve a sustainable higher level of economic
growth by supporting (i) policy and institutional reforms to promote private sector development
and improved public sector management, (ii) human resource development to address the gap
in  marketable  skills  and  improve  employment  and  income  levels,  (iii) enhancement  of  the
country’s infrastructure through public and private investment, (iv) preservation of the country’s
natural resources base, and (v) measures to mitigate the social and environmental impact of the
transition  to  a  higher  growth  path.  The  COS  highlights  the  declining  quality  of  education,  the
mismatch of skills supplied to the labor market, deteriorating knowledge of English and scientific
and technical subjects, more emphasis on creative rather than rote learning, refocusing of the
Government’s role from provider to facilitator of development, and a more rational utilization of
resources including legal provision of funding for private education. In line with the thrust of the
COS  and  ADB’s  overarching  objective  of  poverty  reduction,  ADB  continues  to  support  the
Government’s reform initiatives in the education sector as human development is a prerequisite
for sustainable economic growth. Education will also help both the rural and urban poor acquire
social and physical capital.

32.
The  ADB  education  strategy  in  Sri  Lanka  emphasizes  secondary  and  postsecondary
education. The country has made progress in enrolling all students in school through grade 9.
The World Bank and other aid agencies have focused on the 7,700 schools providing primary
and  middle  school  education.  The  ADB  strategy  is  to  encourage  raising  the  compulsory
schooling level to grade 11 and to ensure that at least half of the students taking the grade 11
national examination pass it. This will improve equity and access to secondary education almost
immediately.  ADB  also  stresses  improving  teaching  in  grades  12-13  to  raise  the  level  of
academic skills in English, science, mathematics, reasoning and computer skills for 17- and 18-
year-olds to give them after graduation the choice to continue with schooling or enter the labor
force in the modern economy. The strategy also allows for greater equity as access to quality
schools for the poor is improved. Secondary education is seen as the foundation of a strong and
equitable education system. In addition to earlier support for general secondary education, ADB
already  has  provided  assistance  for  science  and  technology  (S&T)  and  skills  programs  for
students  who  opt  out  of  the  formal  education  system  prior  to  grade  12  (Loans  1707-SRI  and
1535-SRI, footnote 9). ADB also supports the Government’s need to strengthen postsecondary
education in both the public and private sector. This includes open university/distance learning
and, most important, proprietary education and on-the-job training as a way of increasing public-
private  participation  to  improve  efficiency  and  mobility  opportunities  for  students  after
completing  secondary  school.  In  the  area  of  educational  technologies,  ADB  views  the  level  of
development  in  Sri  Lanka  as  sufficient  to  allow  widespread  use  of  computers  in  secondary
schools to prepare students for the labor market and for postsecondary education and training
where computer use is widespread.

F.

Policy Dialogue

33.
ADB has been involved in education sector policy dialogue with MEHE under SEDP and
TA 3073-SRI: Improving Education Planning (footnote 9) designed to improve school efficiency
and governance. Key issues discussed include (i) provision of full access to quality schooling for
disadvantaged  students  attending  small  schools,  in  an  attempt  to  increase  school  attendance

 11

for  all  from  age  14  to  age  16;  (ii)  strengthening  NETS  to  improve  the  reliability  and  validity  of
national examinations through improved test administration and the introduction of SBA; and (iii)
restructuring  of  MEHE  to  focus  on  policy  and  standards  setting  to  assist  the  local  schools  to
strengthen management and supervision. In addition to specific policies on school access to be
addressed  through  the  project  components,  ADB  has  urged  the  Government  to  improve
efficiency  through  good  governance  and  through  cost  recovery  and  public-private  partnership
designed to guarantee the sustainability of the secondary education system.

1.

Improved Access for the Poor

34.
ADB has pointed out the need to ensure equitable access to schools for the poor. The
Government has provided scholarships, the most common of which is the scholarship program
starting in grade 6 for those who successfully pass a special examination. The Government is
also interested in piloting a program to provide stipends for late bloomers starting in grade 10.
Under the Project, ADB will assist MEHE to introduce two stipend programs (one for grades 10
and 11 students, and the other for grades 12 and 13 students) through block grants to schools
to  provide  disadvantaged  students  with  resources  for  undergoing  remedial  tutoring  and/or
attending better schools nearby. Stipends will be based on academic ability judged by results of
the grade 9 examination for recipients of grades 10-11 awards and the results of the grade 11
examination for recipients of grades 12-13 stipends. Also, a means test for family income to be
determined by the project steering committee will be applied to select disadvantaged students
with high ability who would not pass the grade 11 national examination without assistance. The
stipend  program  is  intended  to  help  increase  the  number  of  students  passing  the  grade  11
examination. Currently, over 90 percent of all students attend grade 11, but only about one third
pass  the  grade  11  examination.  If  the  pass  rate  can  be  increased  through  improved  learning,
students will have the opportunity to complete secondary school. As a consequence, the recent
government  regulation  to  make  education  compulsory  through  grade  9  (age  14)  should  be
modified to apply to grade 11 (age 16), which is considered the minimum for a modern school
system, by 2004. Other activities to improve access to secondary education under the Project
include  career  guidance  programs  by  2002  aimed  at  motivating  students  to  pursue  academic
careers  for  good  jobs  and  the  move  to  improve  public-private  partnerships  in  education  to
reduce the financial pressure on the public education finance.

35.
A second policy initiative related to increasing access pertains to improving the national
examination  system  to  allow  more  students  to  be  successful  in  their  academic  studies.  Under
SEDP, NETS was established to separate national examinations from civil service examinations
under  the  Department  of  Examinations.  NETS  will  require  additional  resources  to  develop
improved  testing,  administrative  procedures,  monitoring,  and  research.  The  Government  has
given  assurances  that  NETS  will  be  fully  staffed  and  funded  over  the  coming  years.  This  is
especially important because NETS has taken on the new role of training teachers in the use of
SBA.  SBA  provides  feedback  to  parents  and  students  of  day-to-day  assignments  on  special
projects  and  schoolwork.  It  also  assesses  attitudes  and  deportment.    Under  the  Project,  SBA
will  be  introduced  in  grades  10-13  so  they  can  be  counted  toward  graduation  along  with  the
national  examination.  SBA  is  most  effective  in  making  school  attendance  important  for  both
teachers  and  students  when  teachers  employ  new  practices  emphasizing  activity-based  study
that  applies  theory  with  practice.  Under  the  Project,  support  for  SBA  will  assess  learning
activities introduced under the Project to ensure that quality improvements stemming from these
activities will contribute to graduation.

 12

2.

Governance

36.
More than anything else, MEHE’s success in overcoming educational inefficiencies will
depend on the quality of its governance, including management and planning linked to regional
and local education institutions. Especially in education, participation by teachers and parents is
necessary  to  generate  ownership  and  sustainability  of  community  resources  in  local  schools.
MEHE  has  been  restructured  to  strengthen  its  planning  function  and  to  devolve  day-to-day
decision making to the local level. ADB encourages this movement through the strengthening of
the  school  inspectorate  to  review  the  learning  requirements  of  teaching  and  through
strengthening the leadership role of principals, provincial, district, zonal and divisional officers in
local decision making with the assistance of the community.

3.

Sustainability

37.
To reduce costs, the concept of public-private partnerships has been raised with MEHE.
Since  nationalization  of  schools  in  the  early  1970s,  education  has  been  almost  exclusively
public  and  private  education  has  been  discouraged.  However,  the  Government  is  currently
unable to expand financial resources for education and other means must be found to pay for
quality  improvements.  One  possibility  is  to  allow  selected  schools  to  collect  fees  to  pay  for
teachers’ salaries. However, these schools would appoint their own boards, pay teachers, and
observe the national curriculum and examinations. Such a public-private partnership scheme for
schools  would  be  fair  because  if  children  from  better-off  households  select  private  schools,
more public money could be targeted toward the poor.  ADB will encourage a study of public-
private  partnerships  in  education  with  the  expectation  that  decisions  to  remove  the  ban  on
private schools will be forthcoming.

38.
Sustainability  also  requires  cost  recovery.    Parents  already  pay  over  20  percent  of
secondary school costs including private tutoring and voluntary school fees. MEHE has agreed
to  have  schools  charge  facility  fees  for  CLCs  to  cover  the  costs  for  software,  electricity,  and
operations and maintenance (O&M) charges.  These fees are levied by SDSs and the funds go
specifically to pay the costs incurred by CLCs.

IV.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A. 

Rationale

39. While Sri Lanka has achieved progress in basic human development, it has been unable
to translate these achievements into broad-based, sustainable economic growth. Worse still, the
rural  poor  have  not  had  equal  access  to  human  resources  necessary  to  acquire  social  and
physical  capital.  A  key  reason  for  this  failure  to  achieve  more  rapid  economic  growth  with
greater  equity  is  the  deficiency  of  the  education  system.  Strong  state  dominance  and  an
inflexible  regulatory  framework  that  limits  choice  have  characterized  the  system.  There  is  an
overreliance on national tests as opposed to SBA, as well as a mismatch between ability to pay
and  secondary  school  educational  services  offered.  There  is  little  choice  in  the  quality  of
education  especially  for  the  poor,  access  to  stipends  or  opportunities  for  public-private
partnerships  are  limited  and,  finally,  supervision  and  management  style  from  the  national  to
local level are inadequate. These conditions have created an inefficient and inflexible secondary
education system that restricts curriculum choice and occupational opportunities, and one that
graduates  students  unequipped  with  marketable  skills  and  unprepared  to  participate  in  the
modern  economy.  The  result  is  relatively  high  unemployment  among  the  educated  while

 13

emerging  modern  sector  employment  opportunities  are  unfilled  due  to  lack  of  qualified
candidates. Sri Lanka views modernization of secondary education as one of the main pillars of
its  drive  for  economic  and  social  development  and  a  key  to  reducing  regional  disparities.
Consequently,  there  is  no  alternative  but  to  improve  school  quality  by  raising  standards,  to
improve access especially for the poor through greater choice of quality curriculum offerings and
to  improve  administrative  efficiency  through  strong  school  leadership  and  administrative
decentralization.

B. 

Objectives and Scope

40.
The  objective  of  the  Project  is  to  improve  the  quality  of  secondary  school  to  raise
national examination results for one million grades 10-13 students in 2,300 secondary schools
nationwide.  Improved  education  will  increase  classroom  learning  and  raise  pass  rates  on
national examinations. The Project will also improve access to these quality improvements for
disadvantaged students through stipends and by upgrading existing secondary schools to full-
curriculum  schools  in  disadvantaged  areas.  This  will  ensure  that  up  to  50,000  additional
students  each  year  for  12  years  will  pass  the  grade  11  national  examination.  The  Project  will
improve  management  and  supervision  throughout  the  national,  provincial,  and  local  education
institutions so that teachers and principals will have greater control over classroom learning as it
affects school efficiency.

41.
The  Project  has  three  components:  (i)  quality,  (ii)  access,  and  (iii)  efficiency.  Quality
involves (i) school-based student learning activities and assessment for core subjects in grades
10-13,  and  (ii)  expanded  computer  technology-directed  learning.  Access  will  (i)  broaden
educational opportunities by expanding by 100 the number of full-curriculum schools in remote
areas,  (ii)  extend  stipend  programs  to  over  30,000  academically  qualified  poor  students,
(iii) introduce  career  guidance  in  all  secondary  schools  to  enhance  students’  educational  and
occupational  choice,  and  (iv)  conduct  studies  on  cost  recovery  in  secondary  education  and
based  on  the  finding  of  the  study  recommend  a  public-private  partnership  model  to  make
secondary  education  competitive.  Efficiency  will  improve  the  delivery  of  educational  services
through (i) quality assurance within MEHE and the strengthening of local supervision and SBM,
(ii) SBA in grades 10-13 including modernizing the national examination administration at NETS;
(iii) NIE curriculum development and in-service training in new A level technology stream, career
guidance,  and  computer  training;  and  (iv) project  implementation  at  the  PMO.  The  project
management structure and design summary are found in Appendix 3.

A.

Financial and Economic Analyses

76.
Sri  Lanka  has  done  well  in  keeping  students  in  school  through  grade  11,  but  not  in
ensuring that they learn well or learn relevant materials.  Consequently, the quality of education
has suffered and put youth at risk of being unemployable in the modern economy.  As the global
and  national  economy  improve,  the  demand  for  educated  employment  will  increase  and
students  will  have  more  and  more  opportunities  for  modern  employment  in  the  private  sector
only  if  they  can  communicate  well,  and  possess  quantitative  and  analytical  reasoning  skills  to
solve problems posed in the modern workplace. As the country must compete more efficiently in
the regional and global economy, the youth need education geared to improving language skills,
computer  skills  and  science  and  mathematical  skills  needed  to  expand  opportunities  and
mobility. Higher pass rates on national examinations can help certify to the quality of what was
learned in school.

77.
  The  major  benefit  arising  from  the  Project  is  the  additional  students  who  successfully
complete grades 11 and 13 examinations. Success will lead to higher income and perhaps an
opportunity  to  continue  their  education.  Increased  earnings  in  a  competitive  labor  market  are
taken  as  a  proxy  for  the  incremental  social  benefit  in  the  economic  analysis.  The  incremental
income received by a successful grade 13 examination candidate is the value to the economy of
the successful candidate whether or not the candidate continues schooling. It is estimated that
225,000 students or about two in every three students fail to qualify to enter grade 12 annually
and are prevented from continuing their formal education. To meet the educational requirements
of  the  modern  economy,  the  education  system  will  have  to  improve  internal  efficiency  by
increasing the number of grade 11 successful examinees by 500,000 over a period of 12 years
(100,000  in  the  first  four  years  of  the  Project  and  400,000  in  the  following  eight  years).  As
standards  cannot  be  lowered  without  jeopardizing  the  credibility  of  the  examination  system,
increases  in  percentages  qualifying  to  enter  grade  12  will  have  to  come  from  improved  test
scores  as  a  result  of  improved  classroom  learning  due  to  better  teacher  pedagogy,  improved
learning materials and activities, and continuous student assessment.

2.

Institutional Benefits

85.
MEHE  will  benefit  from  the  Project  through  support  for  its  restructuring  already  under
way. The Quality Assurance Division that includes support for supervision from the province to
the  zonal  levels  and  into  schools  will  be  given  training  and  resources  to  strengthen  ongoing
supervision.  The  division  will  be  strengthened  with  the  addition  of  a  quality  assurance  unit  to
develop and implement a SBM system that links zonal education offices with principals and the
community.  SBM  is  intended  to  provide  a  degree  of  decentralization  to  secondary  schools  so
that  management  decisions  for  day-to-day  school  operations  can  be  made  in  the  field.  As
school  enrollments  decline,  surplus  secondary  school  teachers  will  be  reassigned  to  do
guidance  and  counseling  and  handle  computer  education.  Other  teachers  will  improve  their
pedagogical skills to ensure that they do not become obsolete.

86.
NETS  is  undergoing  institutional  reform  to  move  toward  an  examination  system  that
provides  useful  feedback  in  a  timely  manner  to  all  students,  regardless  of  whether  they  will
continue  education  or  enter  the  workforce.  A  reliable  and  legitimate  national  testing  system  is
the  basis  of  public  confidence  in  the  education  system  and  therefore  has  to  be  strengthened.
The use of SBA carried out in schools throughout the year will give importance to student effort.
Administrative efficiency in examination reform will reduce time wasted waiting for examination
results  and  subsequent  placement  by  up  to  six  months.  This  has  economic  consequences  as
students do not have to wait around before continuing their classes. NETS will benefit from the
Project  as  the  expanded  staff  are  trained  and  operations  are  improved  to  provide  greater
efficiency and autonomy to the institution.

3.

Efficiency Benefits

89.
The efficiency of the secondary education system will improve as a result of the Project.
Improved  test  administration  will  lead  to  faster  turnaround  in  disseminating  test  results  and
placement, reducing the time by six months for grade 11 examinees and by 12 months for grade
13 examinees.  The introduction of SBA will make assessment fairer as classroom performance
will  count  toward  the  national  examination.  Another  social  justification  besides  improved
academic  test  performance  is  the  value  of  useful  computer  and  language  skills  to  give
secondary  school  graduates  access  to  knowledge  and  information.  This  will  help  narrow  the
digital  divide  between  communities.  Career  guidance  programs  will  also  provide  students  with
information  leading  to  greater  education  and  occupation  opportunities.  Equity  programs  that
allow  students  greater  choice  and  mobility  in  attending  schools  are  also  seen  as  promoting
system  flexibility  to  allow  greater  access  to  improved  schooling.  Finally,  improved  school
administration  especially  in  school  supervision  and  SBM  is  expected  to  increase  local
administrative efficiency, which is essential to a modern school system.

91.
Approximately  21  percent  of  Sri  Lanka’s  population  live  in  absolute  poverty.  This

This  lack  of  impact  may  be  due  in  part  to  earlier  efforts  that  were  not  socially  targeted  and  in
part  to  the  civil  conflict  that  has  displaced  hundreds  of  thousands  of  people  from  their  homes
and  source  of  livelihood.  In  1998  the  Government  with  the  assistance  of  the  United  Nations
Development  Programme  (UNDP)  and  the  World  Bank  undertook  an  extensive  poverty  study.
The  results  show  that  rural  poverty  continues  to  be  quantitatively  and  qualitatively  worse  than
urban poverty and that people who live in poverty work in low-skill and low-paying occupations.
It  appears  that  while  Central,  North  Central,  Uva,  and  Sabaragamuwa  provinces  have  the
deepest poverty, nonetheless, all districts (21 of 25) except five in Western Province combined

C.

Risks

93.
The Project is designed to specifically help achieve the Government’s secondary school
reforms  to  improve  quality,  access  and  efficiency.  Commitment  at  the  national  level  is  strong
despite  the  civil  conflict  that  threatens  public  security.  However,  specific  reforms  requiring
reorganization  of  secondary  school  administration  and  additional  principal  and  teacher  efforts
directed at evaluating student achievements may meet with initial resistance from teachers who
fear  an additional workload. The introduction of SBA in grades 6-9 received a mixed reaction,
with  teachers  agreeing  with  the  need  but  finding  the  additional  burden  of  time  constraining.
Modifications  have  been  made  and  under  the  Project  intensive  training  and  follow-up  will  be
provided to ensure that teachers are prepared to undertake SBA. Once teacher assessment is
included in the national examination score, parents, students, and teachers will begin to see the
value of the additional assessment and this should lead to overall support. A second risk has to
do  with  the  move  to  greater  decentralization  at  the  provincial  and  school  level.  Greater
decentralization  will  require  greater  administrative  capacity.  The  Project  proposes  the
establishment of a secondary education unit within MEHE to provide increased coordination so
that  NETS  and  NIE  are  able  to  accommodate  teacher  training  and  that  PMO  can  administer
block grants for school stipends and involve the community in decisions to establish and support
CLCs  in  project  schools.  As  Sri  Lanka  moves  toward  introducing  IT  and  interactive  learning,
resource planning at the school level will be required. Under the Project, principals and teachers
will  be  trained,  and  SBM  will  be  strengthened  to  ensure  local  financial  support  for  these  new
technologies. Service contracting by suppliers will also ensure computer maintenance.

Description of Project Interventions

3.
Curriculum  Materials  and  School-Based  Assessment.  The  Project  will  provide
consultants to develop materials and activities for key subject areas that will allow students to
be  graded  by  teachers,  with  coursework  used  for  national  evaluation  at  the  end  of  grades  11
and 13. Grade 11 materials will include learning activities in English and mathematics. Learning
activities for grade 13 will include special laboratory and computer activities in science, English,
mathematics, and commerce. Grade 13 will include textbooks, as these are not used in grades
12-13.  Multimedia  rooms  will  be  established  by  renovating  existing  classrooms  and  providing
them  with  electricity,  security,  and  furniture  for  teachers  to  use  multimedia  materials  such  as
television, video, and audio cassettes to practice language instruction, commerce, mathematics,
and  career  guidance.  Policies  enacted  include  making  career  guidance  and  school-based
assessment (SBA) mandatory in secondary education.

4.
Computer  Learning  Centers  (CLCs).  CLCs  are  a  major  innovation  to  introduce
computer  literacy  including  information  technology  (IT)  and  interactive  instruction  using
computers. Existing classrooms will be converted to CLCs and provided with security bars and
door,  electric  wiring,  carpeting,  air  conditioning  and  furniture.  The  laboratory  have  15-25
computers with compact disk-read only memory (CD-ROM) depending on the size of the school,
with  two  students  sharing  a  computer.  There  will  be  one  central  computer  and  two  printers.
Capacity for networking computers and the Internet will be included but not installed initially until
the CLCs are fully functioning and sustainable. Software (in English) will include windows and
several  spread-sheets  along  with  an  array  of  computer  software  educational  games  and
reference materials in the key subjects. A full-time professional staff will be assigned to manage
the  laboratory  and  one  or  more  grade  13  students  waiting  for  examination  results  will  be
employed on a volunteer basis to assist in day-to-day operational management. A fee of SLRs7
per month will be levied for each student using the facilities. After-school use of computers for IT

will be allowed for a fee of SLRs500 per month. Proceeds will be used to pay for electricity and
maintenance  of  equipment  and  materials.  Policies  being  considered  include  making  computer
courses mandatory for grades 12-13 students.

Stipend Program.   The Project includes stipends of up to SLRs10,000 for grades 10-11
5.
and  13,000  for  grades  12-13  per  year  for  tuition,  fees,  transport,  books  and  lodging  (in
exceptional cases). Funds for stipends will be administered by schools under the supervision of
the  principal  and  awarded  to  disadvantaged  students  based  on  economic  means  testing  and
academic  ability.  Means  testing  will  be  based  on  minimum  family  income  determined  by  the
project steering committee. Preference will be given to students in grades 10-11 with excellent
attendance  and  scholarship  in  grade  9.  The  stipend  program  will  also  accommodate  students
who pass the grade 11 national examination but are in danger of not continuing grade 12 due to
financial reasons. Students in newly established full-curriculum schools and in limited-curriculum
schools  will  be  given  priority  over  students  in  existing  full-curriculum  schools.    Among  the
policies  to  be  proposed  will  be  enactment  of  special  stipend  programs  for  disadvantaged
students  in  danger  of  dropping  out  of  school  after  successfully  completing  the  O  level
examination.

Public-Private Partnerships.  The concept is new in Sri Lanka and studies to support a
policy framework is needed to estimate savings from prospective schools that plan to opt out of
the  present  system.  A  second  study  phase  would  review  the  findings  of  the  government
recommendations  and  plan  pilot  programs  to  initiate  interventions.  Policies  being  considered
include the allowing public-private partnerships in secondary education.

have specific mandate to implement SBM and to strengthen the national, provincial, and local
chain of command through training and programs to give more day-to-day operational authority
to local school principals, SDSs, and zonal education offices. Policies being considered include
MEHE  restructuring  to  include  a  quality  assurance  unit  and  support  for  giving  operational
authority to school principals, zonal education officers, and SDSs.

curriculum  schools  and  the  700  largest  of  the  other  schools  accommodate  all  grades  12-13

10-11  students  are  in  small  schools.  All  secondary  schools  will  benefit  from  the  policies,  and

Poverty  in  Sri  Lanka  is  a  relative  concept  that  until  now  has  not  been  adequately

reason,  district analyses are  more pertinent.  Based on the poverty analysis of districts, some
